item.title: Hugo Igloo theme

item.title: New year, New blog
item.description: New year, a new blog, and some reflections on the past year that has passed . I’m taking the lead for a new Core Facility at the University of Oslo . I also got funding from my university to establish a Hub/Node network, which is an initiative from University IT to facilitate exchange of knowledhe between University staff .

item.title: Reorganising Hugo Content and Aliasing
item.description: Hugo Aliasing is a stickler for good organisation of content . Reorganising Hugo Content and Aliasing has a nice way of dealing with that, which they call [gohugoioio] Reorganisation concept is that people should redirect to the specific page that they should be using .

item.title: Using GitHub Actions to Build your Hugo Website
item.description: Using GitHub Actions is a service that runs Continuous Integration, meaning that using a set-up file you can ask workers (computers run by GitHub) to do certain operations on your repository at certain triggers (at push, pull-requests or even on a schedule with crontab) This is where GitHub Actions shines. It is free and so are its actions for small jobs like what we want to do . To build on Netlify, you need all your content version controlled, in my case with git, and stored on GitHub . This is fine and dandy for text files like markdown, csv data, and images that will not change often.

item.title: Changing your Blogdown Workflow
item.description: Blogdown is usually used with [go hugo], a static webpage builder . Blogdown renders directly from Rmd to html, meaning it circumvents hugo's processing of md` . This can cause some unwanted issues depending on your theme . It can also make it difficult to maintain your webpage over time .
